answers.answer: Hey there,Not sure of the terms you use or the meds you refer to but I can tell you that nearly every anti depressant has fluid retention, oedema, as a side effect. This is certainly on the road to diabetes etc and must be watched carefully as some of the damage is irreversible.I had oedema about 5 years back from a med and din't notice it until too late. I lost feeling in the balls of both feet and have had leg pains ever since. Diagnosed as peripheral neuropathy. The fine nerve endings died and will not regrow pending the G nome project.Most think fluid retention is nothing and so did I. But it's a nasty, nasty problem. Diuretics don't fix it either, they just relieve it now and again.CHeck your meds online and see if oedema is listed. Likely it is.

question: I have been on Celexa 20mg and Trazadone 75mg for about 10 years and prior to that Elavil.  I had to go off the Elavil due to heart palpitations but I really liked it.  Now I am reading that combination medications are causing Type 2 Diabetes.  My PCP has been monitoring my A1C for about 2 years and it is steadily climbing.  Last one was 128.  I really dont want to go on diabetic medications.  I am wanting to wean off the Celexa.  I am not sure how to discuss with my PCP just how to do that. Not sure if while I wean off the Celexa.  Would appreciate any suggestions you may have.
title: Type 2 diabetes and anti-depressants
